pros: Good job if you want to make a couple of dollars as a student. It's also a good opportunity for international students who are not allowed to work off campus.
cons: The payment isn't the best.

pros: caring, welcoming culture and motivated people
cons: I have no particular cons.

job_title: Assistant Director In Enrollment Management in Charlotte, NC
pros: A great sense of autonomy in your work; you are never micromanaged. Sometimes that can play to the extremes... at times you can feel like you have no direction, others you have a perfectly clear idea of what goals you are working toward. Benefits are on par with other institutions. There are so many colleagues at Queens who really love the institution, and it shows when you walk on campus. The culture at Queens is tangible: the staff who constantly work with students understand who we are there to serve.
cons: Upper administration is very disconnected. Many VPs need me to wear my nematic in order to know my first name. Pay is not competitive. Typical with the field, you feel overworked and underpaid at times, but immediate supervisors recognize that and really encourage work-life balance (which doesn't exist). The salary gap between entry-level positions and even mid-level staff is sickening. For a smaller university, it seems very compartmentalized when it doesn't need to be. It can seem that upper administration is more concerned with cultivating donations and updating buildings in order to recruit future students than truly providing for the students that we have now. As a staff member, it can seem like you do not have a voice about crucial matters until a band of students speak up.

pros: Family atmosphere that encourages colaboration
cons: Great staff, but lower-level employees are overworked and underpaid

pros: Flexible hours, and worked well with your classes. Able to move up.
cons: Sometimes you had to work double hours and no one would show up.

pros: - Easy to work with professors
cons:
- Still online
- Low amount of students

review_title: Flat. Routine. The beautiful grounds cover a multitude of dysfunction!
pros: Flexible work schedule and "educator holiday" lifestyle. Free education.
cons: Little room for growth, below industry standard for pay and benefits (very expensive for a family), limited resources and substandard budget. Poverty wage unless you are a faculty member / administrator. Negative and non-affirming personnel and leaders in numerous departments. Low moral due to economic restraints. $ goes to faciliities, but not for employee growth, retention, and student engagement.

pros:
- Two weeks off around Christmas
-Monthly staff coffee/mingle (light breakfast provided)
-Percentage of continuing education tuition covered (you still have to pay taxes on those classes though- watch out). 
- Spouses are no longer included in the tuition reimbursement program- it is as if they are a random applicant.
cons:
- You have to pay for parking (there are different levels/lots)
- The entire university is in debt and in a hiring freeze. Those that leave are not being replaced, & the work is simply absorbed.
- Departments are very segregated. Everyone is in their own "click." 
- Management has their favorites based on the clothing brands they wear
- Management is also known for gossiping about their very own employees. Advice: check who you're sending a rude text message to before actually sending it. 
- Long hours are expected, and don't even think about asking for over-time pay. Managers slip through the cracks with illegally denying you this right. 
- Your biggest con would be taking a job there.

pros: Very nice people to work with.  For the most part people were helpful, considerate and nice to interact with.  Work hours were some what flexible as long as the work was completed. The environment was pleasant, though some areas better than others.
cons: It really depends on who you are working for.  I saw some things change for the worse as my supervisors changed. They need to do a better change or training new employees, and retention of employees would be better with training, clearer expectations and better pay for the working employees.   Not much room for advancement.

pros: Great benefits, everyone who works here is respectful and nice, the students are not as demanding or needy as other places I've worked. Beautiful campus in ritzy part of Charlotte. Tuition is free if you want to pursue graduate degree (or undergraduate if you do not have one already)
cons: Like all places of higher ed, no bonuses and very small salary increases every year. You must change jobs to get paid more.

review_title: If you're looking to coast or enjoy status quo, QU is perfect for you.
pros: Beautiful campus, nice community areas, good location, visually appealing, donors love to give money for buildings, weekly faculty/staff gathering, respected within community.
cons: Nonexistent advancement opportunities, salary not competitive, lack of training opportunities, technology subpar, questionable safety and security, management reactive instead of proactive.

pros: Some of the people that work there make it possible to tolerate the job, but most of them are seeking employment elsewhere. But watch out for the career climbers, they have been ask to spy and tell. You know the ones that don't do their job and put it off on you but claim the credit for it.
cons: Work you to death, no raises, always poor mouthing, Hire you and change job description adding more work that you shouldn't be doing. Give you vacation and holidays but won't let you take them because always understaffed.

pros: Very nice people and usually relaxed atmosphere. Beautiful campus and old buildings.
cons: No type of real rules and what there are (employee handbook) is not followed consistently. Way too much politics between departments and no consistent guidance from above.

pros: The University offered a great work/life balance. It was a great atmosphere to work in and the people were always friendly.
cons: The pay rate was poor and the parking was always a hassle. There did seem to be favoritism among the staff and employees but not to a concerning degree.

pros: The Queens campus is beautiful and most of the faculty are intelligent and committed.
cons: Administration is almost unbelievably disorganized. As with most educational institutions, change is slow but ,unlike most educational institutions, change is sorely needed.

review_title: It feels like one big family!
pros:
The feeling that you are apart of something "bigger" and the feeling of being apart of a big family. Very positive atmosphere.
Summer work hours.
100 % tuition remission.
cons:
Not a whole lot of room to move up.
Salaries may be low but other benefits make up for it.

pros: Easy going.  Always willing to help.
cons: Don't always give all information because they forgot you haven't work there forever.

pros: Engaging work environment that promotes diversity, open communication and team building.
cons: Lack of support from the higher administration.
